Do they have no -- do officers have no such right in -- in Georgia?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I -- I -- to mean summarily?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I mean summarily --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: You mean house like this, put a padlock on it?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To a -- no I didn't say anything about padlocked.
I say that they -- if they know there's a nuisance, public nuisance being committed, do they not have the right to abate that nuisance summarily?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Take away all the stuff.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, I have found nothing in the Georgia law on that.
I -- I have found this though, I -- I have found this, that where officers see, the Georgia law does require that -- were -- when officers see contraband.

There was a case on slot machines, they're -- they're under duty then in there to take it and I -- and -- and these officers, once they were inside the house, were under duty to seize this still forthwith.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But we're not -- we're not in there --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No, we're not in there yet.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But I just like to [Laughs] -- I'm just trying to see whether -- whether the owner has anymore right to summarily abate a public nuisance than public officers of the State of Georgia have?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: It is our position and in the circumstances of this case what Bridgaman found --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He also --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- found the same thing and then --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Bridgaman has found it first and he called the police.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: The police didn't call him.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The police were there though.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: He called the police and although Mr. Elliott would minimize this, I think that Bridgaman was concerned about his house.
He -- he --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, let's assume it was --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- took the police there and he took them there.
Why?I think he took them there.
It's fair for me to say from this record that he took them there to repossess his house and kick these people out.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, Mr. Erdahl, if he has the right and it seems to me the question that the Chief Justice have put to you several times, in -- in the crucial question in this case, namely (a) has the landlord the right loosely speaking to abate the nuisance or at least to find out what's going on.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And if he has that right, he can certainly enforce it --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Call --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) -- somebody else.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's our --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If -- if he -- if he has that right, then we can't go into his motives and find whether his (Inaudible) legal or whether he wants to protect his property.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No, no --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He might --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- fairly --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- might be a great believer in (Inaudible) and yet --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- want to protect his property.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: And we -- we -- our position is that he did have the right summarily to go in by the best means he could find and --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what I'd like to know is what -- what specific statute or what specific law do you rely on to give him the authority to go into the house, where --through -- through a bathroom window, in order to abate a nuisance if the law enforcement officer could not do the same thing?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, I think the landlord's rights of entry --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I know but I'm -- what -- what --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- are -- are greater.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what do you --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where -- what do you rely on to say that they are greater?
That's what I want to find.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I'm relying --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I'm not going to argue -- I don't want to quarrel with you, I want to know the law in which you rely and I'm going to read it.
That that's -- that's all.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is it --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- Tiffany on property or is it --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.
That's it (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- or the provision of the Georgia Code, which is it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No, we -- we find nothing in the Georgia Code --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then you're -- you're relying on the --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- general law of property of an entry --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- of a landlord to the premises.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Have you looked up the cases --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I was about --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- have you looked up the cases in Georgia on that subject?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes, we've -- we've looked at it and couldn't find it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you have not found it.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you have not found it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes, yes.

We quote -- we quote Tiffany, "He may enter, the landlord may enter to view waste, that is to determine where the waste has been committed, provided that this does not involve the breaking of windows or doors -- provided at least that this does not involve the breaking of windows or doors or to post a notice to deny him liability under mechanic lien laws and so forth."
He can -- well, let's leave officer and so forth.
He may no doubt enter without being guilty of trespass for the purpose of complying with police and sanitary orders and regulations.
And he will generally be exempt from liabilities -- ability for acts required by the state or municipal authority

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Assume he must have given some citations, are any footnotes to that text in Tiffany?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Oh, yes (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The nuisance?
Alright.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: And we've got -- we've got --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That for our --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- other cases.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- in other States, but there's no Georgia case, is that it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You seem to be -- you seem to be, what shall I say, reluctant or inhibited?
We -- from I'm speaking for myself.
It's a long time since I knew any property law and I want enlightenment.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: The same is true for me too, Mr. Justice.
We've got these cases cited on -- we don't have -- there's not a Georgia case among them.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How about some sister states?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: California, Illinois, D.C., New York.
There is another case cited in our brief, Martin against Medlin, dealing with implied covenants in a lease hold the State.
There, it must be used for the purposes for which it was rented.
It must be -- and certainly and it cannot be used unlawfully or for an unlawful purpose.
That particular case involved a party house.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did it involve a search and seizure?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No, it did not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What was in those cases involve searches and seizures by the -- by the landlord?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, all I can say on the basis of my reading of the cases is that they sustained in suits by tenants against landlords.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They sustained what?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: They -- the cases sustained -- these are cases -- these are suits by tenants against landlords and they sustained the right of the landlord to enter.
Now, there's -- is one -- they -- they don't however set forth, the mode of entry involved by the landlord, which was claimed to be wrong against the tenant.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, they couldn't be --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: The basis of the lawsuit --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They couldn't be invitations if I won -- they couldn't be cases where the tenant invites the landlord --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Certainly not -- certainly not, otherwise, he maybe suing.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But there -- there must be cases where the tenant, did he consent --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to begin with.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: The -- the right and this is recognized in the law.
The right of the landlord to enter implies the right to enter against the will of the tenant.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you have any cases that involve buildings where the entry is the equivalent of -- of opening a window, a bathroom window and going in to the place?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Quotes that I have found to that is in the allegations in White against Thurber, which is cited --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In the allegations you say?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: In the allegations of the plain -- of the plaintiff tenant.
In White against Thurber, a New York case, cited at page 15 of our brief, forcibly and wrongfully against the will of the plaintiff, entered upon the premises and took down the wall -- down the wall.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what -- what happened there?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, the -- the landlord was directed by the city to do something about this wall, so he went in and did it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, he had -- he had the authority of the law behind it to go in and do that specific act, didn't he?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, the -- the authority had -- the direction of the law didn't tell him how to go about it.
Now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you what provision of the Georgia -- I summed up and got the Georgia Code, according to your citation.
They sent me to code on evidence, that's the number of which you referred.
What's -- what --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Title?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- title of the Georgia Code is it that I can find?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, there are different titles (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That says -- you have at 58 Ga. Code.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: 58 Ga. Code, the provisions on nuisances, misdemeanor and the right of the landlord to forfeit --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I think they --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: --are on 58.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I think they made a mistake, they sent me 38 [Laughs], you said, 58.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: 58, title 58.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Title 58.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Title 58 and the provision on manner of abating nuisances are in Title 72.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Erdahl, you don't seem to argue -- I hadn't -- I just flipped your -- the pages of the brief and I therefore, do not know what's in it.
But you don't seem to argue on the basis of the case within this Court that the question of search is a question of the unreasonableness under -- of the search.

And therefore, I should think as one is not sympathetic with those cases, but taking them as the decisions of this Court, I don't see you're arguing on -- argue that it could hardly redeem the non-reasonable search if a policeman thought that the landlord authorized him to enter.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, I -- I haven't had a chance to get that out yet --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that argued in your brief?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, yes -- yes --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- in this way that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where was it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- under all the circumstances, this was a reasonable search.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I know, but I mean to be more specific.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: On the basis of the rights of the landlord?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm suggesting a line of argument with which, as I've said, I'm not sympathetic but might respect, if we're going to take the starting point of the decisions today.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, on the matter of reasonableness and of course, this is the -- this is the -- of the state officers and of course, this is the test under Elkins.
Bridgaman, the landlord took them to his house, he helped them through the window, he knew what was in there and obviously, he wanted to put a stop to it.
I think it's fair to say that he was interested in repossessing his house and it seemed to it that it was to be -- the wasted any further.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You say he knew what was in there --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: He said he did.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- did he know any -- did he know anymore than the officers themselves knew?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No.
He said, "I know of what was in there by smelling it" and they smelled the same thing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, in the case you argued, Mr. Erdahl, Johnson --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- sometime ago.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This Court had that question that -- do you think that in -- in connection with the smell of opium?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And it was held that odor could be enough to make a search.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: On a warrant.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- if you got a search warrant --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: On a warrant.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- than you should present that to the judge or the magistrate, he might give a search warrant.
So that so far as this case is concerned, it's against you is it not, unless you do depend on the right of the landlord --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- to do what was done.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Right.
And that is precisely the basis on which we do defend it, Your Honor.
I have said twice that if this had been a junket by these officers as in the Johnson case or as in the McDonald case, on their own without more, we wouldn't be here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, do you think the law of Georgia is what controlled as to whether the landlord had a right --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- to do this?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I think the law of Georgia is very important here --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- well, that's just been shown --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- because part of the picture of the reasonableness of what was done.
Now, we -- we cannot assume on this record that these officers would have gone --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I assume that there's a valid law of Georgia, which authorizes a landlord to do that under these circumstances and that -- that settled the question of reasonableness, isn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, the -- the Georgia law --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It might not settle it under the federal law.
It might conceive of them, they might not, that's the reason I asked you because you're defending on Georgia law as to that right?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, there are Georgia statutes which are relevant on this question of reasonableness which I had related.
They're part of the total picture particularly as the nuisance provision and -- and particularly under the statute on -- on Bridgaman's rights as a landlord.
He obviously thought that he had a right to go in as he did.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would that make a difference?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I think it's part of the picture of reasonableness and he -- and the officers obviously thought that he had a right to allow them to go in, to tell them to go in.
That's -- that's clear on this record.
And so as Mr. Justice Frankfurter points out, it boils down to whether this was reasonable action.
And we say it was -- it was in principle and in substance, an entry by the landlord in the assertion of his rights.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That brings you back to where they had the right, doesn't he?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I would find it a little difficult --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, I find --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- it a little difficult to say it was reasonable if he -- or either one of them to do it, if it's against the law for him to do what he did.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, I'm sure that -- that the landlord --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) -- in law, one state or even the state of the Federal Government.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I'm sure that the landlord, Bridgaman in this situation, had he knocked at the door and hadn't been opened to him, which is inconceivable since all there was in the house was a still.
He could've said, "Get out here.
Move!
You're evicted."

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Suppose he had said, "No, we won't get out."
What could he do then?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, he'd have to go to court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: But his mouth would not be shut as to what he saw in there, the still.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you're talking about he has the right to go there and evict them.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, the Georgia law, as far as I can gather from you doesn't -- doesn't provide that that he has a right to go there and either summarily evict them or to summarily abate the -- the nuisance or to do anything else.
He has certain rights of -- of forfeiture.
He has certain rights of entry which he can --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- if he can't get peaceably, he can get through a --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- through a writ.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And he has maybe other rights too, he has a right to inform the police, but does he have the right to go and climb through a closed window of the bathroom in order to look into that house and search it to see if there is any violation of law.
Now, where is your Georgia law for that?
That's the basis (Voice Overlap ) --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: The Georgia law on that is the -- is the common law.
There is no -- the -- I don't -- I am -- we have found nothing in the Georgia law giving a landlord the right to go through a window.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Have you found it in --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: But he --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- any of these statements?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: But he has the right that is centuries old to enter his property, to view waste to -- to collect rent, to make repairs, to stop a nuisance.
That's one of the situations in which Tiffany says, "He has a right to entry -- enter."
And certainly --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Erdahl --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- there was a nuisance here, a very grievous nuisance.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Could you forgive me for saying so, I do not think you have yet, even what you've just said, argued on the basis of this Court's decisions regarding search and seizure.
It is not a course of decision that every entry without a warrant is presumptively an unlawful entry.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is not the line of reasoning that this Court has taken.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That was said even in Trupiano.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It has dealt with unreasonable search as the affirmative authorization.
Unreasonable search isn't the exception to the demand for a warrant.
Otherwise, the cases wouldn't be -- be what they've been that even if there was time to get a warrant, it doesn't matter.
Therefore, the question isn't -- the question is whether in -- under all the circumstances, this was an unreasonable thing to do.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And if the landlord thought he had the right to do, I do not see and it is not a -- isn't on egregious assumption, it isn't defensible assumption.
It's one that one has controversy about as to -- to the extent of a landlord's power.
I don't see how he can argue it's unreasonable, because he might be wrong as to Georgia law.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Right.
Well, you've taken the words out of my mouth, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'll give them back to you.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: And while we don't cover this in our brief, I think I ought to touch on it.

Let us suppose -- let us suppose that Bridgaman exceeded his rights in view of the discussion here, I think I better touch on this.Let us suppose that Bridgaman exceeded his rights when he, not because he enters, he had the right to enter and he had the right to enter against the will of the tenant.
But he exceeded his rights in the mode of entry, in the mode of entry.
That at most, would be a technical trespass against the rights of this man, Chapman.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that where this window partly opened or --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No, it doesn't appear that it was cracked at all, it was unlocked.
All the other windows were locked.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He assumed it was fully closed, but unlocked, is that it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Right.
And I assume further that the reason they could see it was unlocked was because the shade, you know, normally is on the inside of the locked window.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, would it make a difference if the window was opened because even open windows would (Inaudible) go in?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- when he cannot go in.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No part of invitation --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: And as that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- on a window that -- that you have to lift.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: And that -- that, I agree.
And as I've said, this was in substance and in principle, an entry by Bridgaman.
But let us assume that he overstepped his rights in the manner in which he exercised his rights.
The cases in this Court had not allowed the admissibility of evidence to turn on such technical wrongs, civil wrongs.

I refer to Burdeau against McDowell, the case in which McDowell's papers were taken out of his office by private persons without his authorization and the Court said that -- and they were turned over to the United States Attorney for prosecutions, for presentation to agree in jury.
The Court said, "We're not going to stop to consider the wrong done to McDowell or what his rights or remedies maybe against the wrongdoer."

In the McGuire case, the agents had a warrant, search warrant, for liquor and when they executed the warrant, they kept to court and destroyed all the rest and it was claimed that this made them trespasser ab initio, because the destruction, their act of destroying the liquor was illegal and the Court agreed to before it and oppressed it.
But the Court said, "This doesn't affect the validity of the search for and the seizure of and retention of the Court be kept."
They said that was valid, that was distinct from the civil wrong, the wrong done in destroying.
And more recently, in On Lee, the Court reiterated that principle.

It was their claim that you recall, that was the case of the informer who went in wired the sound, radio transmitter into On Lee's Laundry and engaged them in conversation, he was a friend of On Lee and On Lee made the incriminating statements, which were picked up on the radio and heard by an agent outside who had the receiving sense.
And it was contended there that on -- the informer was either a -- a trespasser ab initio or he was a trespasser when he went in, because the entry was fraudulent as against On Lee.

And the Court said there that the McGuire case controls the question and that what -- whether -- whether the informer's conduct was unlawful or not, this did not affect the Government's right to use the evidence.

And I think that this case is an even stronger case for the application of that principle because there, the informer who was guilty of betraying his friend's confidence was acting under the auspices of agents who sent him in wired for sound.
Here, the officers wrecking under the auspices of the landlord who had no ulterior motive, whatever.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was that case a public place -- a public place of business?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes, it was.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They walked in through an open door that the public had --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- had the right to go into and --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's true.
But this was Bridgaman's house and he had rights of entry as a landlord.
Now, I think we can test -- test the question this way, test the principle.

Supposing -- let us suppose that Bridgaman in good faith, on his discovery, had resorted to self-help or -- or had gone and gotten some of his friends to help him and he and his friends went into the house the same way.
There would be -- Chapman would have absolutely no right to complain of his discovery -- of Bridgaman's discovery of his Chapman's still, in Bridgaman's house.
And Bridgaman would be free to -- to testify about it, testify as to what he saw at the still.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well under the case, that's --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's under --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- that's private -- that's true of any private individuals --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) the owners.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's right.
Now --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That had -- what you've just said doesn't depend on -- doesn't -- doesn't stand from the fact that Bridgaman was the owner of this house, but just that he was not an officer, isn't that true?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, yes.
It wouldn't make any difference here if had been a stranger to the house, to the lease.
That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: A burglar broken into the house --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes, a burglar, sure.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- he could've testified.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Sir, I agree -- I agree.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But you want us to decide it on that basis?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Let us further suppose that -- well, of course, it would've been foolhardy on Bridgaman's party to go in himself.
He might've subjected himself to danger.
The moonshiners are not very nice people.
He might have been (Inaudible)
So what is he -- what he did he do?
He did the -- a person, he did -- he did the thing that any natural, normal, law abiding person would do.
He went to get the police.
He went to get the police to protect him and to aid him in the exercise of his rights.
And when they got there, he, as I said before, helped boost Harbin on his shoulders and threw the window.
Now, let's suppose --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You might just --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: As a matter of fact, Bridgaman did testify to like effect as the officers, as to what he saw in the house.
After Harbin got in, unlocked the door, Bridgaman went in and he said there, it was all piled up in the living room.
That's all there were, that was in this house, that -- that still and those mash beds, but to get back.

Let -- let's suppose that when they -- when they got to the house, the officers -- and Bridgaman says, "Go on in" and the officers emerged and said, "Well, I don't know of whether we can go in, but you can go in or maybe you can go in as landlord."
And let's suppose, instead of Harbin being boosted through the window, Bridgaman had been boosted through the window.
Now, I don't -- he then had -- it was his house, he had been boosted through.
He could have then opened the door, called the officers in and really have the same situation has actually occurred here.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Would that have been a good search then?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I think so.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: He might be just (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I think so, the landlord going into his own house not withstanding that he was -- had the aid and the protection there of the -- of -- of the police and not withstanding that he and they may have had in mind to -- to seize a still and -- and catch a moonshiner.
I think that makes no difference.
Now, the short of it is, I don't think that this -- the validity of this entry and that's the beginning and the end of our problem.
I don't think its validity should turn on who went in the window first.
Now, Mr. -- finally, Mr. Elliott said that, I adverted to this -- the decision which we asked for here, putting the -- putting tenants to the -- at the mercy of landlords.
Well, that is not so at all and we had an answer to such a suggestion, a very short time ago in the Abel case.

The -- I think we can depend upon the federal courts and upon this Court to be alert, to prevent any abuse of the rights of landlords to enter and to take in -- enter their premises and to take in police with them.

If there's collusion to circumvent constitutional restrictions on law enforcement, then it will be time to call a halt -- halt and those matters, if they should arise, should -- will depend upon the evidence and the concrete findings in such a situation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't that case turned on the consent of the -- of Abel to -- to let the owner in?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: The consent of Abel to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- let this owner.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: To let the owner in?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I don't understand.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I thought in Abel, the -- the Court said that -- that he had consented to them coming there and taking those let material out of the waste basket.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Oh, yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh well --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Two segments to Abel.
The -- the wastebasket part and the earlier part which occurred when he was arrested by the immigration officers.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but when he was arrested by the immigration officers, that wasn't through the -- through the proprietor of the hotel.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Oh, no.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- they came there with administrative warrant.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's right.
That's what --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- the other things -- the other things that involved the -- the landlord as I recall it, there were done according to the Court with his consent.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: In Abel?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In Abel.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: I don't recall that the landlord, the hotel keeper, the innkeeper --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The hotel.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- had anything to do with it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The hotel, it was a hotel.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Had anything to do with it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If they entered his room.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Oh, oh, yes.
Yes.
I would -- that's why -- yes, the wastebasket in part of the -- yes, but I mean on the entry.
I don't think the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The landlord --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- the hotelkeeper.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- didn't have anything to do with the entry.
That was done by --

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that was done by the administrative crew and the administrative warrant gotten by the -- gotten by the immigration authorities on the information of the FBI.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Yes.
The FBI --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't know how to turn here?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: -- turned it over to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I was outrageous.

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, I -- I used Abel, Mr. Chief Justice, only in answer to Mr. Elliott's suggestion that the decision we asked for here would open wide the opportunities or allusion between landlords and police whereby, they could snoop and get evidence on tenants and landlords that walk in, take the police with them.

I say that only for the proposition that it -- those cases should be taken cared of, if they should arise and on the basis of the particular evidence because after all, as Mr. Justice Frankfurter suggested a while ago, "In all these questions, you always come back to the question of reasonableness, in all the circumstances."

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Very generous of me to make that suggestion, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: robert_s_erdahl
turn.label: Mr. Robert S. Erdahl
turn.text: Well, I intended to get to it Mr. Justice [Laughs] --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't mean generous to you, I mean generous to the idea.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Elliott.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: May it please the Court.
I think we have discussed the number of aspects in all of the aspects of this case.
I do however think, it is most important to consider that we must construe the rights of a tenant in this case, as opposed to the rights of a homeowner.

And I do not think that because a man rents his house that he should use -- lose any of his constitutional rights such as under the Fourth Amendment to contest or to ask that certain evidence be suppressed, simply because, he is the tenant in the house, rather than the owner.
I cannot -- that does not set well with me.
I -- I'm wondering if this case is not reversed.
If the house is owned by the United States Government, if the federal agents couldn't just go in on the same basis that the Government claims that Bridgaman can -- could go in under this case.
And would it not be stripping away the individual rights of those tenants in the various housing projects throughout the country.
I -- I think that it is -- would be too far reaching and would really be a question that this Court is not going to allow, the rights of individuals to be stripped away in that manner.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you.

Have you cited any cases which showed -- tell the -- what is the Georgia law with reference to the right of a landlord to enter a house, if he finds that the law had been violated in it, in a way that may entail some kind of guilt and -- and put some kind of guilt on him?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: Alright.
I have -- I'd like to refer to the two statutes and I think that's all there is under Georgia law that we've already referred.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No cases of any kind?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: 58 Ga. Code 109.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I have that code.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: It -- it says -- it reads as follows, "Common nuisance, places defined as the following are hereby declared to be common nuisances and maybe abated as such upon complaint of the Attorney General or the Solicitor General of the circuit or any citizen or citizens of the county."
And then it goes on and refers to a room used for the manufacture of unlawful -- unlawful manufacture of whiskey.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So that this was, if it was being used for that purpose, a nuisance under Georgia law.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: Yes, in other words, a person, a landlord or any other person must go into court if--

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- they want to abate.
They cannot break and enter either under the Georgia law as it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And I think --

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- stand.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose he had known that this was being used for that purpose and had not reported it, what would've been his liability under Georgia law for that nuisance?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: I think it's very possible that the Court would consider or in any action to takeaway his property, to condemn and takeaway his property, I think they could consider that factor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I have before me, one of the cases cited.

It says, "They have considered it and having reached the conclusion that he had knowledge of it, that they had refused to let his house be unpadlocked when it was padlocked as a nuisance under the statute.
That's the -- under the 96 Ga. Code 802.
Is -- is that your understanding of the law?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: That is, in that particular case, it seems --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- that the owner --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- is it your understanding of the law that --

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: It seems that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- that a guilt and knowledge of the use of his premises by landlord, use of his premises for manufacturing liquor, would subject his property to seizure by the State of Georgia, if he knew about it and -- and made no report of it.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: I can say that it was subjected under the federal laws.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Under the federal rule.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- I cannot reply under the state -- state law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Have you then -- have either one of you cited the federal statute under which that would be the case?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: No, not -- not in our brief.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You say it would be forfeitable under federal law?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: Under federal law.
It could be if it's used for illegal purposes, it could be forfeitable and it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was it not?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: And -- and in an instance, where a landlord fails to report something, he could be therefore, considered a conspirator to the extent of entering into the operation or harboring a criminal activity and therefore subject -- subjected to the penalties that would come to anyone who participated in any such action.
I would also like to refer to the --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: May I ask you please sir, as he -- may I ask you please, sir?
Has he discharged his full duty when he has made the report?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: Yes.
I believe that in this particular case, what we have is this.
Now -- let -- let me make one or two background comment.
The Government says they could've entered to collect rent.
Well, now I -- I don't know what that's got to do with this case.
In -- in other words, a man -- a landlord goes to collect his rent and he knocks on the door and nobody's there, what is he going to do?
Go into bathroom window and find the pocketbooks and collect his rent?
I don't think that that's the case.
I think it has no applicability here.

And getting back to your question, Justice Whittaker, I will say this that I think that this man actually just as any other citizen when it came to his attention that -- that he thought the law was being violated there, he made a report not to the general law enforcement officers, but to the liquor agents.
And when he made that report and told them, "If you come out here, I'll show where it still is," I feel that he had fulfilled his obligations.

I feel that from that point on, it was within the hands of the officers and the officers should have known what to do and it -- the law clearly says what those officers should do in the abatement of an action.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, under your law, could they, the officers, derive any author -- entry authority from him, the landlord?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: Not -- not to the extent of breaking and entering.
There are no provisions that I know of on the -- in the codes of Georgia, in the law of Georgia to allow it.
Turning to the common law, there is no provision there to allow any such entry to the extent of breaking -- of breaking a window or a door.

And by breaking the seal on this house, by opening a closed window is very clearly a breaking and it is not permitted by -- by federal -- by common law and there is no provision under state law for any such action that was -- as was done here.
This was simply -- very clearly, a report to the officers by a citizen that I think the law is being violated and turning it over to the officers to take the proper action.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And you think it's -- and you would regard it as a -- a trespass for him if he's under this duty at least of reporting, to verifying his sense of smell by visual -- by visual proof?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: I think it would've been --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you think that would be trespass?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: I think it would've been trespass for him to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The door was open.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- enter it, to do anymore than he had done before the officers came.
And I think the officers had no more right to do more than he could have done.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Practically yes, but do you think that landlords can't take measures, as one, he could be certain --

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: There was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that they were mashing things up if -- what if he's under a duty to report?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: There was no compelling --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He knocked at the door and found that nobody is in.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: There was no compelling circumstance here.
There was no reason in the world why the officers could not obtain a warrant.
There was full and ample opportunity.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is not the requirements of this Court as to this -- that is not the test of ambiguity.

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: The -- I have two or three other comments that I'll try to be very brief on.

Even though property rights would have been lost, either under this Georgia statute that is quoted in the brief of the Government, I think that that would not strip away from his -- him his constitutional rights.

I also asked the Court to please, if they consider the quoted Section 58 Ga. Code 106 that they also consider the Section 58 Ga. Code 101 which is referred in that Section, but is not quoted in the brief of the Government.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What does that Section provide, Mr. Elliott?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: That Section provide, Your Honor, the term "prohibited liquors and beverages" and that is in quote, used in any law to promote temperance or to suppress the evils of intemperance shall include the following.

One, alcohol, alcoholic liquors, spirituous liquors and all mixed liquors, any part of which is spirituous, foreign or domestic spirits or rectified or distill spirits; absent, whiskey brandy, rum and gin and then two, Venus liquors and beverages, three, "Nothing in this chapter shall apply to fermented beverages made from malt in hold or in thought or any similar beverages."
I feel --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What -- what's the -- to what effect do you quote that?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: Well, in this particular case, there was nothing in this house, but mash.
There -- there was no liquor in this house.
And I do not believe this particular Section has any applicability here because I do not think that was anything in that house that would exercise any forfeiture.
And I also want to point out that the Section provides, shall at the option of the landlord, work a forfeiture.
There's no indication that the landlord exercised any or -- or option to forfeit the rights of this tenant.
There's no indication that he's -- took it upon himself to say, "There is a forfeiture and therefore, you are not required to pay anymore rent under any contract that may exist."

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was the mash made of?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: I'm not sure that I can answer --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does the record show?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- that question.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does the record show?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: The record shows that -- that it was simply mash.
I -- I can't help you on that, sir.
I think it was a type of mash that has been left to ferment, as I understand it.
There was no whiskey involved in this case at all, and none in the house.
So, I don't think there's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does the record show what --

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- applicability of this statute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- does the record show what it was to be if it was carried forth before a provision?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: I -- I'm sorry, I didn't understand your --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did the evidence show what is -- would have been, had the process could've been completed?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: As I understand, I -- I think perhaps it would've been white lightning if the process [Laughter] had been --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean corn liquor --

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: -- had been terminated.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean corn liquor?

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: That would be hard liquor.
What they [Laughter] term as white whiskey or --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: White lightning.
[Laughs]

turn.speaker: j_sewell_elliott
turn.label: Mr. J. Sewell Elliott
turn.text: There is no -- there's nothing in the Georgia law to permit this landowner to do what he did.
I further say that I do not agree with the contention of the Government that -- in other words, they present this argument.
They say that the landlord actually went in and took the -- the agent with him.
I don't interpret the facts and I don't think the facts support that conclusion.
I think, at most, what it was, it was a report to the liquor agent that I think I know where you can find the still and he helped them locate it.
And at that stage of the game, it was turned over to the officers and they should've known exactly what to do and that a warrant was required.
Also, it was a case of going around the house.
The Harbin, who is the officer who entered, went all the way around the house, tried all the windows until he found one that was unlocked and that one he went into.
I also would like to point out that this house or the evidence clearly shows that the house was not back in the woods to such a -- to such an extent that it could not be clearly seen.I
t was a little longer than the length of the courtroom in the -- in the trial court from the road.
It could be clearly seen from the road.
It was not hidden back in the woods as a still house might be.
And I want to thank this Honorable Court for your indulgence in the presentation of this case.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Gentlemen, as to the next case, I think it would serve no purpose to -- to start at this late -- late moment.
We will start fresh on it Monday morning.
We'll recess now.
